image.altText: A graphic shows a left hand operating a phone behind overlays of blurred, neon green computer coding.

items.synopsis: Digicel Pacific's network resources are likely being used by private spy firms to track unsuspecting people on the other side of the world and steal their call, message and location data, according to an expert cybersecurity analysis.

title.children: Telstra-owned Pacific mobile network likely exploited by spies for hire

image.altText: Police at the scene of a fatal accident on the Hume Freeway near Chiltern in north-east Victoria

items.synopsis: A truck collision has claimed the lives of two NSW couples aged in their 70s, continuing a horror year for road crashes in Victoria's north.

title.children: Two roadtripping couples killed in Hume Freeway crash had just stopped for a coffee and a rest

image.altText: Marles stands in front of a military aircraft speaking to media.

items.synopsis: The defence minister says he wants to clear the air over $3 million worth of taxpayer funded flights charged by his office since April last year, but can't for security reasons.

title.children: Defence Minister Richard Marles defends $3 million spend on taxpayer-funded RAAF flights

image.altText: The tails of Qantas planes showing the flying kangaroo pass each other at Sydney Airport.

items.synopsis: The government's decision to block Qatar Airways from adding more weekly flights prevented airfares from being made cheaper, says the boss of the competition watchdog, as Labor's president backs a review of the government's decision.

title.children: Allowing Qatar to add flights to compete with Qantas would have reduced airfares, says competition watchdog

image.altText: Jetstar and Qantas planes next to each other on the tarmac at an airport.

items.synopsis: Qantas boss Alan Joyce has confirmed the airline and its subsidiary Jetstar have about $570 million in unclaimed credits. Here's how to figure out if you're owed a refund or how to redeem your credits.

title.children: Qantas and Jetstar are holding more than half a billion dollars in flight credits. How to figure out what you're owed

image.altText: For Sale signage outside a suburban house.

items.synopsis: After a brief downturn earlier in the year, Australia's housing market is firmly in recovery mode, with CoreLogic data showing house prices increased for a sixth consecutive month in August.

title.children: House prices rise for sixth straight month, with interest rate outlook likely to see 'active' selling season

image.altText: Three people wearing jackets walking among a crowd man smiling on the right, man using a megaphone in the middle, US flag behind

items.synopsis: Two ex-members of the far-right US group are the first to be sentenced for their roles in the US Capitol riots, apologising in court, with one saying he "was seduced by the crowd".

title.children: 'I'm not a terrorist': Proud Boys sent to prison for trying to overthrow US election results on January 6

image.altText: Man with gun stands on war tank

items.synopsis: A man allegedly tried to sell US-made technology to a Russian company that supplies Russia's weapons makers with electronics.

title.children: Man charged with attempting to sell US tech to Russia for 'Putin's brutal war machine'

image.altText: Anthony Albanese sits in a crowd next to Megan Davis.

items.synopsis: As spring 2023 arrives and the referendum campaign begins, it's a far more treacherous landscape for the PM, surely, than he imagined on election night, writes Annabel Crabb.

title.children: As Turnbull took to the train station, the temperature of the Voice debate reached new levels

image.altText: A shirt-sleeved ABC Radio Melbourne presenter Raf Epstein, hands in pockets, photographed smiling on a city street.

items.synopsis: The award-winning journalist says he'll uphold the program's "fearless" standards set by Virginia Trioli, who is returning to TV, while a familiar voice will take on the station's Drive program.

title.children: Raf Epstein moves to Mornings in major ABC Radio Melbourne line-up shuffle after Trioli announcement

image.altText: Neil Mitchell in a radio studio.

items.synopsis: After a broadcast career spanning more than 30 years, broadcaster Neil Mitchell announces he will step down as 3AW morning show host in December.

title.children: Melbourne talkback king Neil Mitchell fires parting shot at Andrews as he calls time on radio career

image.altText: Composite picture of Reserve Bank deputy governor Guy Debelle (left) and Andrew Forrest (right).

items.synopsis: Billionaire mining magnate Andrew Forrest's Fortescue Metals Group loses another of its top executives, as former Reserve Bank deputy governor Guy Debelle quits after 18 months at the company.

title.children: Exodus at Andrew Forrest's FMG continues as third top executive departs in a week

image.altText: Eastern Metropolitan MP Matt Bach smiles in a garden.

items.synopsis: Victorian Liberal leader John Pesutto says he remains confident his party can win the next election, despite MP Matt Bach quitting politics to pursue a teaching career abroad.

title.children: Victorian Liberal leader insists 'we can win' despite key MP quitting politics

image.altText: A kangaroo stands amongst a collection of the world's oldest rock art

items.synopsis: Traditional owners charged with protecting the world's largest collection of rock art are travelling to Sydney to endorse an application for potential United Nation's World Heritage Listing.

title.children: Pilbara traditional owners fly out in bid to better protect 50,000-year-old rock art

image.altText: A man in a boat looks at a dead crocodile lying in the shallows of a river.

items.synopsis: For months, locals and rangers have been discovering the bodies of crocodiles along the Norman River, including as recently as yesterday. Authorities are investigating the "disgusting" crimes.

title.children: At least 14 crocodiles found shot, some beheaded, in Gulf of Carpentaria

image.altText: Five men in a bush setting either carry a baby in front pack or a toddler on their shoulders

items.synopsis: When Gabriel Carazo became a dad, he couldn't find any services in his community to connect and support fathers, so he set up his own.

title.children: Meet the bloke who's building a community of dads to flip the script on fatherhood

image.altText: Composite picture of Reserve Bank deputy governor Guy Debelle (left) and Andrew Forrest (right).

items.synopsis: Australia's share market opens down as Fortescue sees another high profile resignation. Follow the day's business news with our live blog.

title.children: Guy Debelle quits Andrew Forrest's Fortescue Future Industries, ASX down in early trade

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Today, the Albanese government released proposed reforms to the Bankruptcy Act 1966 for consultation. According to the press release from Attorney-General Mark Dreyfus : This paper is a direct result of feedback received through a national roundtable on personal insolvency which I chaired in March this year. As a result of this discussion my department identified the following priorities for further scrutiny: an increase to the bankruptcy      threshold; an increase to the timeframe a      debtor has to respond to a bankruptcy notice; a reduction in the period of      time for which a discharged bankrupt is recorded on the National Personal      Insolvency Index; and amending the Bankruptcy Act      1966 so that an ‘act of bankruptcy’ is not taken to have occurred      where a debtor submits a debt agreement proposal to the Official Receiver,      or where a debt agreement proposal is accepted by creditors. The Australian Government is committed to an effective bankruptcy system that serves debtors while also protecting the rights of creditors. Submissions will close on 29 September 2023 and I encourage all interested stakeholders to participate as the government finalises these important reforms. To access the review’s consultation paper and to make submissions visit the Attorney-General's Department website:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Personal insolvency consultation

featuredLink.title: Personal Insolvency Consultation              - Attorney-General's Department             - Citizen Space

children.content: Today, the Albanese government released
proposed reforms
to the
Bankruptcy Act 1966
for consultation.
According to the press release from
Attorney-General Mark Dreyfus
This paper is a direct result of feedback received through a national roundtable on personal insolvency which I chaired in March this year.
As a result of this discussion my department identified the following priorities for further scrutiny:
an increase to the bankruptcy      threshold;
an increase to the timeframe a      debtor has to respond to a bankruptcy notice;
a reduction in the period of      time for which a discharged bankrupt is recorded on the National Personal      Insolvency Index; and
amending the
Bankruptcy Act      1966

so that an ‘act of bankruptcy’ is not taken to have occurred      where a debtor submits a debt agreement proposal to the Official Receiver,      or where a debt agreement proposal is accepted by creditors.
The Australian Government is committed to
an effective bankruptcy system that serves debtors while also protecting the rights of creditors
Submissions will close on 29 September 2023
and I encourage all interested stakeholders to participate as the government finalises these important reforms.
To access the review’s consultation paper and to make submissions visit the Attorney-General's Department website:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Let's have a look at new Bureau of Statistics data. It's just released lending data for July. You can see in the graph below that new loan commitments for owner-occupiers and investors started to pick up noticeably around February this year, following their sharp falls from last year. But where are things headed now? The value of loan commitments for owner-occupier housing fell 1.9 per cent in July (to $15.6 billion), while for investors it only fell 0.1 per cent (to $8.6 billion).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lending for owner-occupier housing down 1.9pc

children.content: Let's have a look at new Bureau of Statistics data.
It's just released lending data for July.
You can see in the graph below that
new loan commitments
for
owner-occupiers
and
investors
started to pick up noticeably around February this year, following their sharp falls from last year.
But where are things headed now?
The value of loan commitments for owner-occupier housing fell 1.9 per cent in July (to $15.6 billion), while for investors it only fell 0.1 per cent (to $8.6 billion).

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Guy Debelle, the former Reserve Bank deputy governor, has quit Andrew Forrest's Fortescue Future Industries (FFI). The ABC understands it happened weeks ago, well before the recent collection of resignations that have hit the troubled company. But he has now joined Tivan Limited (ASX: TVN), a small cap critical minerals company. Tivan informed the Australian Securities Exchange of Debelle's move this morning, saying he's agreed to join the board of Tivan in the role of non-executive director, effective as of 1 September 2023. "After leaving the RBA, Dr Debelle worked at Fortescue Future Industries as CFO and non-executive director," the statement says. "Other precious positions he has held include: the International Monetary Fund, Bank for International Settlements, Australian Treasury, visiting Professor of Economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, chair of the Global Foreign Exchange Committee, chair of the Council of Financial Regulators working group on Climate Finance, chair of the BIS Markets Committee." Tivan says Debelle has confirmed his intention to invest $25,000 in the company by way of a private placement of shares at a price of 7.2 cents, consistent with the investment made by his fellow directors in the placement announced on 12 July 2023. It says this is subject to the approval of shareholders at the Company's 2023 annual general meeting. Dr Debelle said in a statement: "I am excited to join Tivan who are focused on realising the great opportunity Australia has in the green transition, particularly in the critical minerals space. I am looking forward to working with the team to further enhance Tivan's inclusive and sustainable approach to developing its resources to benefit the community and deliver value for its shareholders."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Guy Debelle quits Andrew Forrest's Fortescue Future Industries

children.content: Guy Debelle
, the former Reserve Bank deputy governor, has quit Andrew Forrest's Fortescue Future Industries (FFI).
The ABC understands it happened weeks ago, well before the recent collection of resignations that have hit the troubled company.
But he has now joined
Tivan Limited
(ASX: TVN), a small cap critical minerals company.
Tivan informed the Australian Securities Exchange of Debelle's move this morning, saying he's agreed to join the board of Tivan in the role of
non-executive director
effective as of 1 September 2023
"After leaving the RBA, Dr Debelle worked at Fortescue Future Industries as CFO and non-executive director," the statement says.

"Other precious positions he has held include: the International Monetary Fund, Bank for International Settlements, Australian Treasury, visiting Professor of Economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, chair of the Global Foreign Exchange Committee, chair of the Council of Financial Regulators working group on Climate Finance, chair of the BIS Markets Committee."

Tivan says Debelle has confirmed his intention to invest $25,000 in the company by way of a private placement of shares at a price of 7.2 cents, consistent with the investment made by his fellow directors in the placement announced on 12 July 2023.
It says this is subject to the approval of shareholders at the Company's 2023 annual general meeting.
Dr Debelle
said in a statement:

"I am excited to join Tivan who are focused on realising the great opportunity Australia has in the green transition, particularly in the critical minerals space. I am looking forward to working with the team to further enhance Tivan's inclusive and sustainable approach to developing its resources to benefit the community and deliver value for its shareholders."

image.altText: Two men with greying hair in suits shake hands on a street watched by other people

items.synopsis: Australia's only Liberal premier is actively campaigning with a Labor prime minister for a Yes vote on a Voice to Parliament, while some of Tasmania's Aboriginal groups are hoping the No vote succeeds.

title.children: Australia's smallest state could play a bigger than usual part in the Voice referendum

image.altText: A young woman stands next to a red car in a car dealership.

items.synopsis: In a landmark case for the Australian automotive industry, the Federal Court has ruled Mercedes-Benz is free to set fixed prices and sell direct to customers, rather than let dealerships haggle, write Vishal Mehrotra and Rajat Roy.

title.children: The days of haggling at car dealerships may soon be over, thanks to this landmark legal decision

image.altText: A person holds a Voice to Parliament official referendum booklet

items.synopsis: The Voice to Parliament campaign is already rife with misinformation. Here are some eyebrow-raising claims you may have seen about the referendum and how you can help ABC Investigations expose more like them.

title.children: Here are some falsehoods you're probably seeing about the Voice and what you can do about it

image.altText: People on a street hold up signs protesting against the release of wastewater from the Fukushima nuclear plant.

items.synopsis: Japanese businesses and citizens living in China suffer a backlash following the release of treated radioactive wastewater from the damaged Fukushima nuclear power plant.

title.children: Japan started releasing treated nuclear wastewater into the Pacific. The reaction in China was swift

image.altText: Senator Larissa Waters speaks over the UNESCO listing of the Great Barrier Reef as "in danger"

items.synopsis: The Greens say the government must pay superannuation on top of government-funded paid parental leave if it wants planned changes to superannuation to pass the Senate.

title.children: Greens threaten to block superannuation changes, demanding super be added to paid parental leave

image.altText: Tally board for the referendum results at the Albert Hall, Canberra, 1967.

items.synopsis: As the Voice to Parliament referendum campaign began in earnest this week, claims resurfaced online that Indigenous people were once governed by a 'flora and fauna' act. RMIT ABC Fact Check investigates.

title.children: This pervasive myth about the 1967 referendum refuses to die

image.altText: Australian Federal Police barrier can be seen outside the house, also trees lined up along fence.

items.synopsis: A Canberra man who attacked three others with a meat cleaver is found not guilty of murder because of mental impairment.

title.children: Canberra man who attacked housemates with meat cleaver, killing one, detained for 30 years

image.altText: five colourful vapes standing on a black-coloured counter

items.synopsis: Around 60,000 illegal vapes with an estimated street value of more than $1.8 million and over $835,000 in cash have been seized in Brisbane this week.

title.children: Tens of thousands of vapes seized from storage units and residences in Brisbane

image.altText: A person draws a syringe of Pfizer coronavirus vaccine in Perth, WA.

items.synopsis: Here's a quick wrap of the COVID-19 case numbers from each Australian jurisdiction from the past week.

title.children: All the latest COVID-19 case numbers from around Australia

image.altText: A girl stands behind a boy, both wearing yellow hard hats and navy overalls, while boy sprays water

items.synopsis: At just 12, Katie Newton is already preparing to become a firefighter. She's a member of Glenlyon's junior fire brigade, which is breathing new life into the local CFA station.

title.children: 'I'll become a firefighter': Junior fire brigades attracting next generation of volunteers in Victoria

image.altText: A close up picture of a blonde woman smiling

items.synopsis: Paul Cannon is sentenced to life in prison for the brutal stabbing of his ex-wife Lynne in what the prosecutor described as an act arising out of festering selfishness and jealousy after he learned she had begun a new relationship.

title.children: 'Coward' husband who savagely murdered ex-wife with kitchen knives out of jealousy gets life sentence

image.altText: A red-haired Kylie Minogue poses with her hands, wearing a a glittery frock against a dark green background

items.synopsis: Kylie ratchets up the 'Tension' with the title track to her new album following the runaway success of 'Padam Padam'. Can lightning strike twice?

title.children: Kylie Minogue drops new club-ready single Tension — but is it better than Padam Padam?

image.altText: Close up shot of Anthony Albanese.

items.synopsis: Thank goodness for Senate committees. This week, they've proved, yet again, to be worth their weight in accountability gold, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: Thank goodness for Senate committees: They shed light on government secrets

image.altText: A star Spanish women's footballer looks off to the side of stage as she stands holding a trophy.

items.synopsis: Spanish superstar Aitana Bonmatí and England coach Sarina Wiegman use their UEFA awards speeches to voice their support for Jenni Hermoso, amid ongoing controversy over the forced kiss by Spanish FA president Luis Rubiales at the Women's World Cup final.

title.children: UEFA player of the year Bonmatí speaks out over Spanish kiss controversy

image.altText: Three pharmacist lined up behind the counter preparing scripts, printing labels and writing out medications.

items.synopsis: Small pharmacy businesses are bracing for changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, which comes into effect today, with patients able to collect double the supply of some medications for the price of a single prescription.

title.children: Pharmacy businesses brace as half-price medication policy comes into effect

image.altText: Boy with cuts on his face and bruising on his eyes

items.synopsis: An investigation is underway after a six-year-old boy was bitten by a support dog at his South Coast school, with reports he was attempting to give the labradoodle a cuddle.

title.children: Year 1 student recovering after support dog bites his face at school

image.altText: A mushroom with a split down the centre popping up through the gravel cement

items.synopsis: A photography exhibition in Manjimup, Western Australia, helps highlight the ecological importance of what some say is a forgotten part of the planet's biodiversity.

title.children: This award-winning photo isn't of a dragon's eye — it's a fungus growing through concrete
